quizzes.title: History Quiz: Person and Ellis Island
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, summer, combustion. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What was the approximate population of the United States at the time of the first census?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 4,000,000

questions.question: Who was the first Major League Baseball pitcher to strike out ten consecutive batters?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tom Seaver

questions.question: What did Oliver Pollock invent?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The $ sign

questions.question: This rock group included Jeff Beck, Jimmy Page, Robert Plant, Paul Schaffer, Nile Rogers, Brian Setzer, Ricky Cool, Kevin ONeil, Robbie Blount, and Andy Silvester. They appeared on SNL and had a #3 hit with a remake of Sea of Love.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Honey Drippers

questions.question: Which statement is true about Samuel Becketts play Breath?

options.text: It has won three awards as a movie script but none as a play.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It lasts about 25 seconds.

questions.question: What did Abraham Lincoln buy in April, 1860?

options.text: A train ticket to Washington, D.C.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cocaine

questions.question: What is Calixa Lavallee famous for?

options.text: She changed her last name to Calista Kay Flockhart and the rest is history.
She invented the Post It Note.
He was the first British soldier killed in The American Revolutionary War.
He wrote the music for the Canadian national anthem O Canada.[

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He wrote the music for the Canadian national anthem O Canada.[

questions.question: Who was born Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lady Gaga

questions.question: Who was the first person to build a working internal combustion engine?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Francois I. de Rivaz

questions.question: April 17, 1907 was the busiest day for new immigrants at Ellis Island. How many New Americans came through Ellis Island on that date?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 11,747

questions.question: He was the first person to be number one on the FBIs Ten Most Wanted list.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas James Holden

questions.question: On September 30, 1955, California Poly student Donald Gene Turnupseed  was driving a Ford. Why is this important?

options.text: Its the opening scene of Its a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World.
He was the first person given a breathalyzer test.
Its the opening scene of Psycho.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: His car killed James Dean.

questions.question: What was to be the name of the site we know as Amazon.com?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cadabra.com

questions.question: The summer of 1871 was abnormally dry for much of the midwestern US. Why was this significant in US history?

options.text: It led to the building of the Hoover Dam.
It led to the Dust Bowl.
It is one of the reasons for the second star in the flag of Chicago.
It led to the Great Depression .

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It is one of the reasons for the second star in the flag of Chicago.

questions.question: This name can refer to a place in Rio de Janiero, a town in Columbia, a famous shrine in Bolivia, a nightclub that opened in New York City in 1940, or a Marx Brothers film.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Copacabana

quizzes.title: Nature Quiz: Charles Dickens and Statement
quizzes.description: Test your nature knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Nature, beguin, mean. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What statement is true about Jacob Roggeveen?

options.text: He was the first European to land on what is now Indonesia.
He was the first European to land on Easter Island.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was the first European to land on Easter Island.

questions.question: Which unfortunate event happened five years before Charles Dickens death?

options.text: The death of his first-born child
The death of his wife Catherine Hogarth

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Staplehurst train crash

questions.question: In 1610 Jean Beguin published Tyrocimium Chymicum. What statement is true about this book?

options.text: It was the first book to postulate intelligent design.
It was the first book published in the Western Hemisphere.
It was the first book of lectures given by Sir Isaac Newton.
It was the first chemistry textbook that did not deal with alchemy.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It was the first chemistry textbook that did not deal with alchemy.

questions.question: What does the word doulocracy mean?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rule by slaves

questions.question: In what year were emoticons used for the first time?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1857

questions.question: Which of these jobs did Charles Dickens work before becoming a popular novelist?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: Charles Dickens was an English novelist of the Victorian era.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What is lateral epicondylitis commonly known as?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tennis elbow

questions.question: When was the Eighty Years War fought?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1568-1648

questions.question: Which word refers to the footprint of large animals?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pugmarks

questions.question: In 2002 this nation became the first tо make euthanasia a non-punishable offense.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Netherlands

questions.question: As a child, Charles Dickens worked at a boot-blacking factory.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: In 1712, there was a slave rebellion in the USA. Where did it occur?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New York City

questions.question: How many children did Charles Dickens have?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ten children

questions.question: Gads Hill Place was the country home of Charles Dickens.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What statement is true about Isaiah Sellers?

options.text: He was the steamboat captain from whom Samuel Clemens copied the name Mark twain.
He financed Levi Strauss clothing ventures.
He sold the rifle that Lee Harvey Oswald used to kill President Kennedy.
He was the de facto President of the USA for one day after Harrison died and before Tyler took office.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was the steamboat captain from whom Samuel Clemens copied the name Mark twain.

questions.question: Who was the first head of the US Weather Bureau?

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chester A. Arthur

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Garfield

questions.question: Which list of words came from the Dharug language?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: wallaby, dingo, wombat, koala

questions.question: What statement is true about Annie Moore?

options.text: She was the first new American to enter through Ellis Island.
She was the first female US soldier to die in combat.
She was the first female spy hired by the US government .
She was Axis Annie, the European equivalent of Tokyo Rose.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: She was the first new American to enter through Ellis Island.

questions.question: Who was the mother of King Henry I of England?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Matilda of Flanders

questions.question: What are Waterloo Teeth?

options.text: A French expression for the poorly made scalpels used during the early 19th century
A British expression for the knives used at the Battle of Waterloo
False teeth made from teeth extracted from soldiers killed at Waterloo
Special swords expressly made for Wellingtons soldiers

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False teeth made from teeth extracted from soldiers killed at Waterloo

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Franklin D. Roosevelt

questions.question: Which of these is the translation of the Latin phrase exitus acta probat?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The end justifies the means.

options.text: He had problems with the police because of street fights.
The family was in desperate need for money.
